Spotting error.explanation: 'An hour' will be used in place of 'a hour' in the above sentence. Because 'hour' is a vowel sounding word so article 'an' will be used before it.

Spotting error.question: A Earth moves round the Sun.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'The' Earth' will be used in place of 'A Earth', because definite article 'the' is used with celestial bodies (Earth, Sun, Moon etc.)

Spotting error.question: We were busy at the work and went for lunch only at 2.30 pm.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'at work' will be used in place of 'at the work'. The definite article 'the' is usually not used before 'work'. Because in the sentence 'work' is used in indefinite sense and uncountable noon.

Spotting error.question: Rice of a best quality is available in the nearby supermarket at eighty rupees per kilo.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'The best' will be used instead of 'a best', because article 'the' is used before superlative degree.

Spotting error.question: Two elderly ladies narrated an rather improbable story to the police.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, the use of 'An rather' is incorrect. In its place ' rather an' will be used because the use of 'an' is used for improbable story in the sentence. Note –: Improbable is pronounced with 'vowel sound'. Therefore before this, indefinite article 'An' will be used.

Spotting error.question: In the northern suburbs of Bengaluru, home to the bulk of the information technology industry, the water crisis is even worst.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, ' is even the worst' will be used instead of 'is even worst'. Because in the given sentence 'worst' which is superlative form of bad and 'the' is used before the superlative degree.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'No error'
The day before yesterday he left for Europe by the air.
Spotting error.explanation: The phrase 'by air' is appropriate in place of 'by the air'. The word 'by' is used before the medium of transport without the article 'the' (e.g., By air, by railway, by road, by water).

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
We will use enamel paint on this wall because it gives a best finish.
Spotting error.explanation: 'The best finish' should be used instead of 'a best finish' because the definite article 'the' is used before a superlative degree.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
With this heat wave on, we are having a terrible weather.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Terrible weather' should be used instead of 'a terrible weather'. 'Weather' is an uncountable noun, and therefore, an indefinite article (a/an) is not used before it.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
The young girl was helping her father to look after shop.
Spotting error.explanation: 'To look after the shop' should be used in place of 'to look after shop'. 'Shop' is used as a definite noun in this sentence, so the definite article 'the' should be used before it. 'A/An' is used before indefinite nouns.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment which contains the grammatical error.
Climate change are a greatest threat facing our planet which needs our immediate attention.
Spotting error.explanation: 'The greatest' should be used instead of 'a greatest'. The definite article 'the' is always used before a superlative degree.

Spotting error.question:
In the given sentence, identify the segment which contains a grammatical error.
I think Virat Kohli will remain the captain of the Indian team in a year 2020.
Spotting error.explanation: 'In the year 2020' is appropriate instead of 'in a year 2020', because the article 'the' is used in a definite sense, and 'year 2020' gives a definite sense.

Spotting error.question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has as error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
Teachers Day shall be observed (1)/ as non– teaching day (2)/ in our campus (3)/ No Error (4)
Spotting error.explanation: 'As a non-teaching day' should be used in place of 'as non-teaching day'. 'Day' is a countable noun and is used in an indefinite sense, so the indefinite article 'a' should be used before it.

Spotting error.question:
In the sentence identify the segment which contains the grammatical error.
According to a recent study, drinking green tea thrice a week is associated with a longest and healthy life.
options: drinking green tea thrice a week
Spotting error.explanation: 'The longest and healthy life' is appropriate instead of 'a longest and healthy life'. The definite article 'the' is always used before a superlative degree, and 'longest' is the superlative form of 'long'.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the given sentence which contains the grammatical error.
Most of voters in Taiwan seem to have once again voted for the democratic party and President Tsai Ing-wen.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Most of the Voters' should be used in place of 'most of voters'. The structure 'most of + the + plural noun' is used.

Spotting error.question:
In the given sentence identify the segment which contains the grammatical error.
When I met Akbar Padamsee, one of a pioneers of Indian art, he was 87 but still alert and active.
options: one of a pioneers of Indian art
Spotting error.answer: **one of the pioneers of Indian art**
Spotting error.explanation: 'One of the pioneers of Indian art' should be used instead of 'one of a pioneers of Indian art'. After 'one of', the article 'the' and a plural countable noun are used. Therefore, 'the' should be used in place of 'a'.

Spotting error.question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
An Country's Central News Agency (1)/said the launch was a (2)/''muscle-flexing''. (3)/ No Error (4)
Spotting error.explanation: 'A' should be used in place of 'An' before 'Country's'. 'A' is used before a consonant sound, while 'An' is used before a vowel sound. However, if the pronunciation of a consonant starts with a vowel sound, 'An' is used.

Spotting error.question:
In the following question, the sentence may have errors Find out which part of the sentence is an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
However, the essential services (1) / and critical staff in a government (2) / will be on duty today (3) / No Error (4)
Spotting error.explanation: 'The government' is appropriate in place of 'a government' because 'Government' is used in a specific sense in this sentence, requiring the definite article 'the'.

Spotting error.question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has as error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
We look forward to an (1)/ successful working relationship (2)/ in the future (3)/ No Error (4)
Spotting error.explanation: 'A' should be used instead of 'an' before 'successful'. Article 'a' is used before words that start with a consonant sound ('successful'), while 'an' is used before vowel sounds.

Spotting error.question:
In the following question, some part of the sentence may have errors. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the appropriate option. If a sentence is free from error, select 'No Error'.
A ethos of equality was one (1)/ of the major reasons for their (2) / belief in 'satguru'. (3)/ No Error (4)
Spotting error.explanation: 'An ethos of equality' is correct. 'Ethos' starts with a vowel sound, therefore the indefinite article 'an' should be used before it.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
Patralekha finished the cake in the blink of a eye.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Of an eye' is appropriate in place of 'of a eye'. 'Eye' starts with a vowel sound, so the article 'an' should be used before it.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
Nisha rejected the job offer as a salary offered was too low
Spotting error.explanation: 'As the salary offered' should be used instead of 'as a salary offered'. The use of 'salary' is appropriate in a definite sense in this sentence, thus requiring the definite article 'the'.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error.
Due to a last minute snag, the mission on a moon had to be cancelled.
options: Due to a last minute snag
Spotting error.explanation: Instead of 'on a moon', 'On the Moon' is appropriate. The definite article 'the' is used before celestial objects of the world like Sun, Moon, Earth, Planet, North Pole, South Pole, Equator, etc..

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error from the given options.
Outside the cinema hall, there was queue of people waiting to see the movie.
Spotting error.explanation: Article 'a' should be used before 'queue'. Articles 'a/an' are used before singular countable nouns.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error from the given options.
They visited the Qutub Minar, which is most attractive spot in Delhi.
Spotting error.explanation: 'The most' is appropriate in place of 'most'. The article 'the' is used before a superlative degree (e.g., much-more-most).

Spotting error.question:
Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose ‘No error’.
Can you please pass me that glittery pen black?
Spotting error.explanation: The correct sequence of adjective and noun is 'adjective + noun'. So, 'glittery black pen' is correct.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentences has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
It can / get extreme cold / during / the winters.
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'extremely' should be used instead of 'extreme' because it modifies the adjective 'cold'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
The food container / is not enough big to meet / the demands of the affected people.
options: the demands of the affected people.
is not enough big to meet
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'enough' always comes after the adjective it modifies. 'Big enough' means sufficient to fulfill a need or requirement.

Spotting error.question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.
a) Don't talk so loudly. b) Rama can bowl fastly. c) Go back to your room. d) Run quickly.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Fastly' should be replaced with 'fast'. 'Fast' functions as an adverb and does not require '-ly' at the end to form an adverb.

Spotting error.question:
Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose ‘No error’.
What is the price of this fancy dress pink?
Spotting error.explanation: If more than one adjective is used before a noun, the proper sequence is size/shape/age/color/origin/material/purpose. Thus, 'Pink fancy dress' is correct.

Spotting error.question:
Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose ‘No error’.
Its impossible to conduct truly causal research on media consumption and suicide.
Spotting error.explanation: 'It's' (meaning 'it is') should be used in place of 'Its' (possessive adjective) because a subject + verb structure is needed in the sentence. 'Its' is not used as a possessive pronoun here.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error. If there is no error, then select the option 'No error'.
The credit for organizing/the successful event was/ given to both Neha and I.
options: given to both Neha and I.
Spotting error.explanation: The objective case 'me' should be used in place of 'I' because an objective case pronoun is used after a verb or preposition (like 'given to').

Spotting error.question:
Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose 'No error'.
A key institution is the judiciary, especially the Supreme Court, with a widely remit and a wise legacy.
options: a widely remit and a wise legacy
A key institution is the judiciary
Spotting error.answer: **a wide remission and a wise legacy**
Spotting error.explanation: After the article 'A', an 'adjective + noun' structure should be used. 'Widely' is an adverb and 'remit' is used as a verb here. Therefore, 'a wide remission' is appropriate.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains theerror from the given options.
They were / married happily / before she / quit her job.
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'happily' should precede the verb 'married' to qualify it. So, 'happily married' is the correct placement.

Spotting error.question:
Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose 'No error'.
India has turned 70 years older as a Republic.
Spotting error.explanation: According to the sense of the sentence, the adjective 'old' in the positive degree is needed. 'Older' is a comparative degree used with 'than' to show comparison between two objects.

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Everyone should respect those parents, teachers, and elders.
Spotting error.explanation: When 'everyone' or 'everybody' is the subject of the sentence, the possessive pronoun 'their' or 'his' should be used.

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
This is the book whom I wanted to buy.
Spotting error.explanation: The relative pronoun 'which' is used for non-living things. 'Whom' is used for living things in the objective case.

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
In many places, restoring mangrove forests can be an extreme effective strategy
Spotting error.explanation: 'Effective' is an adjective, so the adverb form 'extremely' should be used to modify it.

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
Educators must roll up their sleeves and do a more best job of teaching critical thinking.
options: Educators must roll up their sleeves
and do a more best job
Spotting error.explanation: Comparative degree ('more') and superlative degree ('best') are not used together. Additionally, the article 'the' is used before a superlative degree.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The mountain / seems to steep / for us / to climb.
Spotting error.explanation: The structure 'too + adjective + to' is used to convey a negative sense, which is suitable for this sentence.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
One must not boast about their success.
Spotting error.explanation: The possessive pronoun for 'one' is 'one's'.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'No error'.
At one time birds and animals lived peaceful together.
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'peacefully' should be used instead of the adjective 'peaceful' because it modifies the verb 'lived'.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
A misunderstanding has crept between he and his sister.
Spotting error.explanation: The objective case pronoun 'him' should be used after the preposition 'between'. 'He' is used as a subjective case pronoun.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'No error'.
If you are going downhill you can go much fast.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Very' should be used instead of 'much'. The adverb 'very' is used to modify the adverb 'fast'. Generally, 'much' is used before an adjective.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error. If there is no error, select 'No error'.
You should tell these children to complete their projects himself.
Spotting error.explanation: The subject 'children' is plural, and the plural possessive adjective 'their' is used for it. Therefore, the plural reflexive pronoun 'themselves' should be used.

Spotting error.question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select 'No substitution'.
Her coach allowed she swimming in deep water.
Spotting error.explanation: After the verb 'allowed', the pronoun should be in the objective case, followed by the infinitive 'to swim'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
It is difficult to say/which of the/two girls in that house/is the eldest?
Spotting error.explanation: The comparative degree 'elder' should be used in place of 'eldest' because a comparison is being made between two persons/things.

Spotting error.question:
In the sentence identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
There are much advantages of working together in a group.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Many advantages' should be used in place of 'much advantages'. 'Many' is used to refer to a large number of countable nouns.

Spotting error.question:
In the given sentence, identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Draw a lotus plant and label their parts.
Spotting error.explanation: The possessive adjective 'its' should be used instead of 'their' because 'its' is used for non-living things and shows belonging to a thing.

Spotting error.question:
In the given sentence, identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
A community is a group of people who shares a common culture.
Spotting error.explanation: 'That' would be appropriate instead of 'who' because 'group' refers to a non-living entity in this context, and the pronoun 'that' is used for non-living things.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
I will come to yours house in the evening to play chess.
Spotting error.explanation: 'To your house' should be used in place of 'to yours house'. 'House' is a noun, and a possessive adjective ('your') is always used to qualify a noun. 'Yours' is a possessive pronoun.

Spotting error.question:
In the given sentence, identify the segment that contains a grammatical order.
There is a few water in the bowl on the table.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Few/a few/the few' are used before countable nouns, while 'little/a little/the little' are used before uncountable nouns. 'Water' is an uncountable noun, so 'a little' should be used.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The birds flew/fastly above/as we stood/on outterrace.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Fast' should be used in place of 'fastly'. 'Fast' is an adverb used to modify the verb 'flew', while 'fastly' is an incorrect word.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I am not sure/if the red car/ in the parking slot/is your.
Spotting error.explanation: According to the sense of the sentence, a possessive pronoun ('yours') is required at the end, not a possessive adjective ('your').

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. if you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
He sat down in a darkly corner and covered his face, and would not say a single word to anyone.
options: and covered his face, and would
He sat down in a darkly corner
not say a single word to anyone
Spotting error.answer: **He sat down in a dark corner**
Spotting error.explanation: 'He sat down in a dark corner' is appropriate instead of 'He sat down in a darkly corner'. 'Corner' is a noun, so the adjective 'dark' should be used before it, not the adverb 'darkly'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I find that / I get myself tired / very easily / these days.
Spotting error.explanation: The use of the reflexive pronoun 'myself' is superfluous in this sentence.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. if you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
They had hardly completed / half of the work / than the boss called them.
Spotting error.explanation: The word 'when' should be used in place of 'than' because 'when' is used with 'hardly' or 'scarcely' (Scarcely/Hardly...when).

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My friend / who's leg / was fractured, / has recovered.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Whose leg' should be used instead of 'who's leg'. 'Who' is used as a subjective case, while 'whose' is used as a possessive case (acting as an adjective).

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
If he wants/ farther information,/ send him/ to me.
Spotting error.explanation: The segment 'farther information' is grammatically incorrect. 'Farther' means 'at a distance', while 'further' means 'next' or 'additional', which is required here.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part the contains the error from the given option.
This question / is quite too / simple for me / to answer.
Spotting error.explanation: The part 'is quite too' contains an error. 'Quite' and 'too' have similar meanings in this context, making 'too' superfluous.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The recently hike/in the price of petroleum products/will hit/household budgets severely.
options: in the price of petroleum products
Spotting error.explanation: 'The recent hike' should be used in place of 'The recently hike'. 'Hike' is a noun, and the adjective 'recent' should be used before it, not the adverb 'recently'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My older brother,/ which you’ll / meet later,/ is a dentist.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Whom' is appropriate instead of 'which' because the relative pronoun 'whom' (objective case) is used for a person, while 'which' is used for animals or things.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My house / is more / spacious than / my sister.
Spotting error.explanation: Instead of 'my sister', 'that of my sister' should be used, or 'my sister's house'. Comparison should be made between the same noun (house).

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
It feels greatly to be with you at this ceremony.
Spotting error.explanation: 'It greatly feels' should be used in place of 'It feels greatly'. The adverb 'greatly' modifies the verb 'feels' and should precede it.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
Solar storms can / impact Earth-dwellers ' in significantly ways.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Significant' should be used in place of 'significantly (adv)'. The adjective 'significant' is used to qualify the noun 'ways'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He had begun to dig / diligent along the / low tideline and had / captured two clams.
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'diligently' should be used to modify the verb 'begun', while 'diligent' is an adjective.

Spotting error.question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select 'No substitution required'.
The playground was way large then I had imagined, and in cleaning it, my back began to ache.
Spotting error.explanation: The sense of comparison is being displayed, and in the comparative sense, 'than' is used for comparison. Therefore, 'larger than I had' is appropriate.

Spotting error.question: A man tends to one / of the horses after it's / training at a stud farm.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Of the horses after its' should be used instead of 'of the horses after it's'. 'Its' is a possessive adjective used before the noun 'training', whereas 'it's' is the short form of 'it is'.

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
When you are under significant stress, it is hardly to process details and nuances.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Hard' should be used in place of 'Hardly'. According to the sense of the sentence, the adjective 'hard' provides a suitable meaning and is used after 'it is'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer.
The mountain lion is / one of the slyest and more / elusive animals in the woods.
options: one of the slyest and more
Spotting error.explanation: When different parts of speech are connected by 'and', they should be parallel. 'Slyest' is a superlative degree, so the superlative degree 'most' should be used after 'and'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The brightest stars/can be 30,000 times/most luminous / than the Sun
Spotting error.explanation: 'More luminous' should be used in place of 'most luminous' because the presence of 'than' indicates a comparison, requiring the comparative degree 'more'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
May I / please borrow / yours book?
Spotting error.explanation: 'Your book' should be used in place of 'yours book'. The possessive adjective 'your' is used before the noun 'book', while 'yours' is a possessive pronoun.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Laughing for about ten minutes / continuous each day / is supposed to be / good for your health.
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'continuously' should be used in place of the adjective 'continuous' because an adverb is needed to qualify the whole clause (the action of laughing). Adverbs qualify verbs, other adverbs, adjectives, prepositions, and sometimes whole clauses.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Philip was / too proud / for extending / a hand of friendship.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Too...to' is used in the sense of 'so much that', and after 'to', the base form of the verb is used. Therefore, 'to extend' is correct.

Spotting error.question:
Parts of the given sentence have been given as options. One of them contains a grammatical error. Select the option that has the error.
Pray to the Almighty God with utmost devotion and help the needy and poored people.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Poor people' should be used in place of 'Poored people'. 'People' is a noun, and the adjective 'poor' should be used before it.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This apartment / is / nice than / that one.
Spotting error.explanation: Since 'than' is used to indicate comparison, the comparative degree 'nicer' should be used instead of 'nice'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The children played / merry in the park / while their parents / kept a watch.
Spotting error.explanation: The adverb 'merrily' should be used in place of 'merry' because an adverb is needed to modify the verb 'played'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, select 'No error' as your answer.
However hardly you / may work, / nobody will praise you.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Hard' should be used instead of 'Hardly'. 'Hardly' is a negative word and is not suitable according to the sense of the sentence; the adverb 'hard' is needed here.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don't find any error, select 'No error' as your answer.
This newspaper has/a bigger circulation/from any other newspaper.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Than' should be used in place of 'from' because 'than' is used with comparative degrees.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment which contains a grammatical error.
Deepu's mother / has repeated asked him/ to lower the volume / of his mobile.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Repeatedly' should be used in place of 'repeated'. An adverb is appropriate to modify the verb 'asked'.

Spotting error.question:
In the given sentence, identify the segment which contains the grammatical error.
The government has announced a gradual reboot of air travel who was halted two months ago due to lockdown.
Spotting error.explanation: 'That was halted' is appropriate in place of 'Who was halted'. 'Who' is used for living things, while 'that' is used for non-living things as a relative pronoun.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
After a long gap,/we went shopping/last sunday and bought/ that we wanted.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Which we wanted' should be used instead of 'that we wanted'. 'Which' is used for non-living things as a relative pronoun.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error the given options.
The food/in the new eatery/is much best than/the one in RK Puram.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Is much better than' should be used instead of 'is much best than'. The comparative degree 'better' is used before 'than'.

Spotting error.question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The army/marched fearless/towards/the enemy cantonment.
Spotting error.explanation: Instead of the adjective 'fearless', the adverb 'fearlessly' should be used because the adverb modifies the verb 'marched'.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
The small cafe at the end of the road is her.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Hers' should be used in place of 'her'. A possessive pronoun is appropriate to show possession, while 'her' is a possessive adjective.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
She has been a member of this club since it's formation.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Its' should be used in place of 'it's'. 'Its' is a possessive adjective, and it precedes the noun 'formation'.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
The three of them shouted out to each another when the train started moving.
Spotting error.explanation: 'One another' should be used in place of 'each another'. 'Each other' is used for two people, while 'one another' is used for more than two.

Spotting error.question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
Nikhil is more braver than Sushant who is afraid of the dark.
Spotting error.explanation: The word 'more' and 'braver' are both comparative degrees, and double comparatives are not used together.

Spotting error.question: No matter he tries hard he cannot play the guitar.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'how' will be used after ' No matter' because no matter is followed by verb/adverb. Correct sentence- No matter how hard he tries, he cannot play the guitar.

Spotting error.question: My sister and myself are pleased to accept your invitation to dinner.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'I' will be used in place of 'myself', because Reflexive pronoun (myself) is not used as a subject.

Spotting error.question: The cheetah can run more faster than any other animal.
Spotting error.explanation: 'More and faster' will not be used together, because both are comparative and double comparative is not used together.

Spotting error.question: I had to hold on to the wall to steady itself or I could have fallen.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'to steady myself' will be used in place of 'to steady itself'. Because the reflexive pronoun of the subject 'I' is 'myself'.

Spotting error.question: The information you are asking for is quite irrelevance.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Is quite irrelevant' will be used in place of 'is quite irrelevance' in the above sentence, because an adjective is required to modify the information (noun) in which 'irrelevant' will be used. While 'Irrelevance' is used as a noun.

Spotting error.question: Nobody has ever listened to me so attentive.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'so attentively' would be appropriate instead of 'so attentive'. because adverb 'attentively' would be appropriate for verb 'listened' not adjective 'attentive'.

Spotting error.question: There isn't many rice left in the house so we must replenish our stock soon.
Spotting error.explanation: 'There isn't much rice' would be appropriate in place of 'There isn't many rice' in the above sentence, because 'rice' is a singular uncountable noun for this 'much' is used while 'many' is used with uncountable noun. example- much rice, much milk, much bread (uncountable noun) many students, many pens, many cats (countable noun).

Spotting error.question: He is more smarter than his brother though he does not earn much money.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'He is smarter will be used instead of 'he is more smarter', because double comparative degree can not be used together.

Spotting error.question: I know the cobbler which mends the shoes outside the gate of our colony.
Spotting error.explanation: 'Who mends' would be appropriate in place of 'which mends' in the above sentence. Because in the given sentence, the use of 'which' is wrong for cobbler. because Cobbler is a living thing for which relative pronoun 'who' is used. 'Who' is used for living thing while 'which' is used for non-living thing and 'that' is used for both (living and non-living).

Spotting error.question: With food granaries overflowing, the Government is looking to liquidate his grain stock to prevent damage.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'its' will be used in place of 'His'. Because possessive adjective 'its' is used for the government' (non-living thing).

Spotting error.question: How many money did Sudhir win in the lottery?
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'how much money' would be appropriate in place of 'How many money'. Because 'money' is an uncountable noun. 'Much' is used before uncountable noun.

Spotting error.question: Vini bought two new dresses but either is suitable for the festival.
Spotting error.explanation: 'But neither is' will be used instead of 'but either is' in the above sentence. Because the use of 'neither' would be appropriate for negative sense. Neither- not one nor the other of two things or people.

Spotting error.question: They informed the teacher that all of they family members would be going to Visakhapatnam.
Spotting error.explanation: 'All of their family members; would be appropriate instead of 'all of they family members' in the above sentence. Because the possessive adjective of 'they' is 'their' which qualify the family members.

Spotting error.question: The team began searching for reasons for their poor performance in the tournament.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'for its poor performance' will be used instead of 'for their poor performance, because 'team' is a collective noun. Which is used in singular. So with 'team' third person singular pronoun (its) will be used. Whereas their is used for plural noun (they).

Spotting error.question: Deepak said he would pack few things he had and vacate the hostel room the next day.
Spotting error.answer: pack the few things he had
Spotting error.explanation: 'The few' will be used in place of 'few' in the above sentence. Few – not many (in the sense of negative) A few – some (in the sense of positive) The few – some (whatever is but all).

Spotting error.question: Very little metals are as precious as gold.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'few will be used in place of 'little' because 'few' is used for countable things. While 'little' is used for countable things.

Spotting error.question: Billionaire Philip is the owner of the luxury yacht Lionheart, which worth an estimated $150 million.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'Whose worth' will be used in place of 'Which worth'. Because the subject of the sentence is alive and relative pronoun who/whose is used for living things.

Spotting error.question: We can see much changes in Government schools these days.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Many changes' will be used in place of 'much changes' beacuse 'Many' will be used with countable noun. (change).

Spotting error.question: You must make a choice immediately because there is few time left.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'little time' will be used instead of 'few time', because 'few' is used with countable noun, while 'little' is used with uncountable. (time).

Spotting error.question: Queen elizabeth got marrying to Philip, former Prince of Greece and Denmark.
Spotting error.explanation: In the place of 'marrying', 'married' will be used in the above sentence, because in any sentence, either noun or adjective is used after verb. Hence, Adjective' married' will be used after got.

Spotting error.question: The park was well lighted at night but it was deserted, so it was a bit scared.
options: so it was a bit scared
Spotting error.answer: so it was a bit scary
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'so it was a bit scary' will be used in place of 'so it was a bit scared', because adjective scary (something or someone that causes fear of terror. Which gives proper meaning for the sentence.

Spotting error.question: There are some members who haven't paid his subscription yet.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, their subscription yet' will be used in place of 'his subscription yet' because the subject of this sentence (some members) is plural. Hence, plural possessive adjective (their) will be used for it.

Spotting error.question: All these boys have come to college without few knowledge of English.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'without little knowledge' will be used in place of without few knowledge. Rule– 'few' is used as a countable noun and 'little' is used uncountable noun while knowledge is uncountable noun. Hence, before 'knowledge' 'little' would be appropriate.

Spotting error.question: Cats cannot be blamed for its behaviour to their masters as they are tamed so.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'For their behaviour' would be appropriate instead of 'for its behaviour'. Because 'its' is used for non-living things. While the subject of sentence is 'cats' (living thing). Hence possessive adjective (their) would be appropriate for it.

Spotting error.question: The performance of our players is worst than I had expected.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'worse than' will be used instead of 'worst than', because comparative degree is used before 'than'. Bad → Worse → Worst positive comparative superlative.

Spotting error.question: Yesterday I searched in every my cupboard for the shirt I couldn't find.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'instead of' in every my cupboard', 'in every cupboard' would be appropriate. Because possessive adjective is not used after every.

Spotting error.question: I don't recognise a none of the politicians who have been invited to be the speakers today.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'I don't recognise any of ' will be used in place of 'I don't recognise none of'. Because the use of 'don't. makes it clear that Sentence is negative. Hence 'none' will not be used but 'any' will be used. which gives negative sense.

Spotting error.question: I know that he wanted to go home earliest./ No error.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'early' (adverb) will be used instead of earliest (adjective). Because an adverb will be used to modify the verb, (go).

Spotting error.question: She ran so fastly that I could not overtake her./No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Fast' will be used instead of 'fastly' because 'fast' is an adverb itself, which modify the verb (ran).

Spotting error.question: My brother brought a few rice while coming from the market./No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'a little rice' will be used instead of 'a few rice', because 'A few' is used as a countable sense and 'a little' is used uncountable sense. While 'Rice' is an uncountable noun. Hence the use of little would be appropriate.

Spotting error.question: Pallavi is the cleverest of the two sisters./No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the given sentence, 'the cleverer' will be used instead of 'the cleverest' because the comparative degree is used for two men or two things and superlative Degree is used more than two men or two things.

Spotting error.question: He did not have few hopes when he contested the election./No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Any' would be appropriate instead of 'few' because 'any' is used for negative sense and 'hope' would be appropriate instead of 'hopes' because 'hope' is an uncountable noun. Note- Any is used in the sense of negative and interrogative sentence.

Spotting error.question: It was not possible/for we/to understand her/No error.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'for us' will be used instead of 'for we', because the pronoun comes in objective case after the preposition. Hence, the objective case of 'we' will be 'us'.

Spotting error.question: The recently announcement about various government schemes impacted the society positively.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'recent announcement' will be used instead of recently announcement. Because 'announcement' is a noun in sentence. Hence Adjective 'recent' will be used to qualify before it, not recently (adverb).

Spotting error.question: After the match, every player of the team went back to its house.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'To his house' will be used instead of 'to its house' because in sentence, subject is 'every player of the team', which denotes singular person. So 'his' would be appropriate as a possessive adjective for singular person.

Spotting error.question: Rita was a model so she would starve herself to maintain their body weight.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'her' will be used instead of 'their'. Because possessive adjective 'her' would be appropriate for Rita (girl). Note– 'Their' is a possessive adjective of 'they'.

Spotting error.question: David and me are brothers but from different mothers.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'I' (subjective case) would be appropriate instead of 'me' (objective case) because 'same part of speech' join with and. Note:– All pronouns are used as subjective case before main verb.

Spotting error.question: The master did not know who of the servants had broken the glass.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'which' will be used in place of 'who'. Because which of the + plural noun/pronoun is used. Here 'which' would be appropriate and gives suitable meaning for the sentence.

Spotting error.question: The essay is divided into five paragraphs and every of these has seven sentences.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'Each' will be used instead of 'every', because 'each' would be appropriate as a pronoun, while 'every' is only used as an adjective. Notes- Every is only used as an adjective, while 'each' is used both pronoun and adjective.

Spotting error.question: Grandmother was knitting a sweater for his grand-daughter.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'her' will be used instead of 'his'. Because possessive adjective 'her' is used for female (Grand-mother). While 'his' is used for masculine gender.

Spotting error.question: It's important for media to be more responsibly and careful.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'More responsible' will be used in place of 'more responsibly' because when two words joined by 'and', both the words are used in the same parts of speech. Hence 'careful' is used as an adjective then, Responsible (adjective) will be used instead of responsibly (adverb). Note :– In sentence An adjective is used to modify media (noun), not an adverb.

Spotting error.question: He lost all his hardly earned money./ No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Hard' will be used instead of 'Hardly', because 'Hardly' is used as a negative sense, while 'hard' is used as a positive sense which gives suitable meaning.

Spotting error.question: Don't worry, there is less time for the train to arrive./No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the given sentence, according to the sense, 'much' is used in place of 'less'. Because it is clear from the use of 'don't worry' make it clear' that there is still more time for the train to arrive. Hence the use of 'much' would be appropriate.

Spotting error.question: She loved herself so more that she thought of no one else./No error
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'So much' would be appropriate instead of 'so more', because here 'more' is used as countable sense while 'much' is used as uncountable sense. In this sentence, 'love' is used as uncountable sense.

Spotting error.question: It would take up few of my time to explain to you the whole case./No error
options: explain to you the whole case
Spotting error.answer: a little of my time to
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'A little of my time to' would be appropriate in place of 'few of my time of' because adjective 'a little' is used for uncountable noun. While 'a few' is used for countable sense.

Spotting error.question: Nowadays spectacles are costly than they used to be.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, in the sense of showing comparison, 'costlier' would be appropriate in place of 'costly'. Because comparative degree is always used to show comparison and it is clear from the use of 'than' in the sentence.

Spotting error.question: She was known for her skills in dance and music; she is equal proficient in the allied art of painting.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'Adverb, 'equally' would be appropriate instead of 'equal'. Because adverb is used to modify an adjective (proficient).

Spotting error.question: When Mayank came, / I shall go / with him to / the circus.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above given sentence, the segment – 'when Mayank came ' is grammatically incorrect, because the sentence is showing the condition, when the first clause is in simple present, then the second clause will be in simple future tense. (When + first clause (simple present), second clause (simple future tense)].

Spotting error.question: If you plant a seed, / you will be noticed / that it takes some / time to grow.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'you will notice' will be used instead of 'you will be noticed', because in this type of conditional sentence if one clause is in present tense, the main clause is future indefinite tense.

Spotting error.question: If he had not dropped out, / he will most certainly have completed / his education by 2023.
options: If he had not dropped out
he will most certainly have completed
Spotting error.answer: he would most certainly have completed
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'he would most certainly have completed' will be used in place of 'he will most certainly have completed', because 'if in first clause' had + v3 is used then in second clause 'would have + v3' will be is used.

Spotting error.question: Has the situation / been favourable, / I would have / attended the marriage.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'had' is used instead of 'Has' because the sentence is conditional and if 'would have' is used in second clause then had + V3 form is used in the first clause. Note – 'Had' is used at the beginning of the sentence to show the condition.

Spotting error.question: He wonder for a moment if he had mistaken the direction.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'He would have wondered' will be used instead of 'he wonder' If + sub + had + v3 ......would have + v3.

Spotting error.question: That man would have attacked you, if you went that way.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'If you had gone' will be used instead of 'if you went'. Because when 'would have' is used in principal clause, then 'if + had + V3' is used in sub-ordinate clause.

Spotting error.question: When he goes on a business trip, he is usually taking his wife.
options: he is usually taking his wife
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'takes' will be used instead of 'taking'. Because the above sentence is showing condition in such sentences, if first clause is in present indefinite. then the second one will also be in present indefinite. Note :– 'verb1 + s/es' is used with singular subject in present indefinite tense and simple sentence.

Spotting error.question: She will come to work though it doesn't rain tomorrow.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence The use of (if) would be appropriate instead of 'though', because if would be used as a conjunction in conditional sentence. Which gives appropriate meaning to the sentence.

Spotting error.question: If so many catches had not being dropped, we would have won the match.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'been' would be appropriate instead of 'being'. Because the given sentence is conditional sentence, type III and passive voice is used in 'if clause'. A.V.– If + had + V3 ...... would have + V3 P.V.— If + had + been + V3 ...... would have + V3.

Spotting error.question: No sooner did he see the tiger when he ran as fast as he could.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'than' will be used instead of 'when'. Because co-relative conjunction 'than' is used with No-sooner' Rule- No sooner did →V1st........... than No sooner had →V3rd........... than but- Hardly had →V3rd........... when Scarcely had →V3rd........... when As soon as →V3rd..........., (comma) All these rules are used in the same sense.

Spotting error.question: Entering the hall, the show had started.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'entered' will be used instead of 'entering'. Because as a rule, there is a sense of having two actions in the past, then for the action that happened first, the verb is in pasts perfect and for the action that happened later, the verb is in past indefinite.

Spotting error.question: If I knew about him before I will have recommended him.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'would have' will be used instead of 'I will have' because given sentence is mix conditional whose structure is as follows. If + simple past, would have + V form.

Spotting error.question: We will rest for sometime when we will reach the top.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'When we reach' would be appropriate instead of 'when we will reach' because when two correlated sentence is in future tense, then subordinate clause is always in present indefinite tense and principal clause is always in future indefinite tense.

Spotting error.question: If the growth of population had been controlled earlier, mankind wouldn't lived in a polluted world now.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'Mankind wouldn't have lived' would be appropriate instead of 'mankind wouldn't lived'. Because if clause is a conditional sentence whose correct syntax is as follows- If + sub + had + ...., sub + would + have + v3 + ...

Spotting error.question: Had you/not reached in time,/we will have/lost our lives.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'we would have' will be used instead of 'we will have' because the sentence is in conditional sentence and in the first clause of conditional sentence- Had + V3 and in second clause would have + V3 is used. Note- Had + Subject + V3 + Other word + Subject + Would/Could/Might + have + V3 + Other word.

Spotting error.question: No sooner did the comedian begin his act when the audience roared with laughter.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Than' will be used instead of 'when' because the structure rule of no sooner in the sentence is as follow- No sooner did + VIst .......... than No sooner had + VIIIrd .........than.

Spotting error.question: When the boys were playing the match, it suddenly starts raining.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'started raining' would be appropriate in place of 'starts raining'. Because 'when' is used as a conjunction and introduces sub ordinate clause. In this situation, main clause is used in simple past. Hence the use of V2 form would be appropriate.

Spotting error.question: If India will win this match they will win the series.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'If India wins this match' would be appropriate instead of 'if India will win this match'. Because 'will/shall (modals) is not used in if clause. If + simple present,.... ..... simple future.

Spotting error.question: If I join a software company I am getting a good deal of experience.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'I will get' would be appropriate instead of 'I am getting', because in conditional sentence 'if' clause is in the present indefinite, then the letter second clause will be used in future indefinite.

Spotting error.question: Rakesh was studied when his friends called him.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'studying' will be used instead of 'studies'. Rule - If some work is going on in the past and in the meantime. Any event happened (for a short time) then ongoing work is kept in past continuous and the event that happened in the middle is kept in 'past' indefinite.

Spotting error.question: Had Rajani not taken/a cab to the station/she would have definitely/miss the train.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'missed the train' would be appropriate instead of 'miss the train'. Rule- IIIrd Conditional sentence structure. [If + subject + Had + v3 ---sub +would have + v3] or [Had + subject + v3, --- subject + would have + v3].

Spotting error.question: Having worked for the whole day, you shall have taken some rest and begun again.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'You should have taken, will be used instead of 'you shall have taken', because it is the conditional sentence of past in which 'should have + VIIIrd form' would be appropriate.

Spotting error.question: If children are treating with respect, they will behave accordingly.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'are treated' would be appropriate in place of 'are treating'. Given sentence is conditional sentence type-1, in which if clause is used in simple present tense and main clause is used in future indefinite tense. If + simple present, will / shall V form because 'if' clause is in passive voice. Hence, use of the are + V3 would be appropriate.

Spotting error.question: If I had gone to the library I can have borrowed a book.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'could have' would be appropriate in place of 'can have'. The Given sentence is conditional type-III. Whose structure is as follows– If + past perfect, (would have / could have) + V form.

Spotting error.question: If they had a playground here, they can play after their school is over.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'they could play' would be appropriate instead of 'they can play' Because this is conditional sentence of simple sentence whose structure is– If + subject + simple past tense + subject + would/could/might + verb in base form (V3).

Spotting error.question: I just don't like the themes of todays music.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'today's' will be used in place of 'todays' because to show Possession Apostrophe ('s) is used with related noun. Today's music – Music of Today.

Spotting error.question: We bought / two dozen's / mangoes from / the market.
Spotting error.explanation: Some numbers (hundred, thousand, lakh, Million, billion dozens) are used both singular and plural. If definite number (one, two, three.....) has been used before them, then their plural is not made. So we will replace two dozens with two dozen.

Spotting error.question: My neighbour's grandson / is only / five month old.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'Months' will be used in place of 'Month'. Because plural noun is used after five (plural number).

Spotting error.question: It was a surprising / to receive the gift/ from my brother.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'A surprise' will be used instead of 'a surprising' because according to the sense of sentence, Noun form is required here.

Spotting error.question: They finally did what / we advice them to do / before the final match.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'we advise (verb) them to do' will be used instead of 'we advice (noun) them to do', because verb (advise) is used after subject 'we', not noun (advice).

Spotting error.question: Human being are / the producers and the / consumers of Earth's / resources.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence Instead of 'Human being are', 'human beings are' will be used because 'Human being' is always used in plural sense.

Spotting error.question: Land revenue was one of the / major / source of income / for Britishers in India.
options: land revenue was one of the
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'major sources of income' would be appropriate instead of 'major source of income', because plural noun (Major Sources) is used after 'one of the'.

Spotting error.question: The man turned to him with a look of disapprove.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Disapproval' (noun) would be appropriate instead of 'disapprove' (verb) because according to the sense of sentence, Noun form (disapproval) is required here.

Spotting error.question: The manager told/the staff to complete/all the works/before going home.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'all the work' will be used in place of 'all the works', because 'work' is an uncountable noun and uncountable noun is not made plural by adding 's/es'.

Spotting error.question: He loses his tempers on the slightest provocation.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'his temper on' will be used in place of 'his tempers on', because 'temper' is an uncountable. Hence its plural will not be formed.

Spotting error.question: The man played the flute and led all the mouse out of the town.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'Mice' will be used in place of 'Mouse', because 'all' is used with plural noun and 'mice' is the plural number of 'mouse'.

Spotting error.question: The chart papers were distributed among all the childrens.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence Instead of 'childrens', 'Children 'will be used because'. Children is a plural number of 'child'.

Spotting error.question: The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. Public speaking/is one of/ the most feared form/of communication.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'forms' will be used in place of 'form' because plural noun is used after 'one of the'. Correct Sentence - Public speaking is one of the most feared forms of communication.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error. The furnitures in this shop is very costly.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Furniture' will be used instead of 'furnitures' because 'furniture' can not be formed plural by adding 's/es'. Correct sentence- The furniture in this shop is very costly.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error. The childrens are fond of climbing the mango tree in the garden.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'the children' will be used instead of 'the childrens', because children itself is plural, its singular is child. Hence there is no need to make plural by putting 's' in it. Correct Sentence :- The children are fond of climbing the mango tree in the garden.

Spotting error.question: Select the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error. They had to wait for the luggages to be put into the cab before they themselves got into it.
options: before they themselves got into it
to be put into the cab
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'for the luggage, will be used in place of for the Luggages, because plural of luggage can not be formed by adding 's/es'. Correct Sentence : The had to wait for the lugguage to be put into the cab before they themselve got into it.

Spotting error.question: In the sentence identify the segment which contains the grammatical error. Subhash Gidwani is selling dolls, which are type of Madhya Pradesh's village culture at the Annual Dastakar Bazaar, held in January every year in Delhi.
options: held in january every year in Delhi
which are type of Madhya Pradesh's village culture
Spotting error.answer: which are type of Madhya Pradesh's village culture
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'the village culture of Madhya Pradesh' will be used instead of 'Madhya Pradesh's village culture. Because apostrophe 's' is used for living thing noun to form possessive case and 'of' is used for non living thing to form possession. Correct Sentence :- Subhash Gidwani is selling dolls, which are type of the village culture of Madhya Pradesh at the Annual Dastakar Bazaar, held in January every year in Delhi.

Spotting error.question: Select the segment in the sentence, which contains a grammatical error. This furnitures has been taken on hire for the function in the college.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'This furniture has' would be appropriate instead of 'this furnitures has' because the plural of furniture is not formed by adding s/es. One piece of furniture Two pieces of furniture Correct Sentence :- This furniture has been taken on hire for the function in the college.

Spotting error.question: In the given sentence identify the segment which contains the grammatical error. The Commonwealth Games had a grand opening ceremony with spectacular cultural performings.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'cultural performances' would be appropriate in place of cultural performings. Because 'noun' will be used after cultural (adjective). Hence the use of performance (noun) is appropriate. Correct Sentence :- The Commonwealth Games had a grand opening ceremony with spectacular cultural performances.

Spotting error.question: Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose 'No error'. Her relatives were presented at the station to see her off.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence Present (Noun) will be used in place of 'presented' (verb) because if were presented (III form of verb) is used in the sentence, it will be in passive voice. Which will not give proper sense. Correct Sentence :- Her relatives were present at the station to see her off.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error. It is not possible to discuss anything with her because of her angry.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Because of her anger' will be used instead of 'because of her angry' because 'angry' is an adjective' while noun is used after her (possessive adjective). Hence here 'anger' will be used because as a noun. Correct sentence :- It is not possible to discuss anything with her because of her anger.

Spotting error.question: Find the part of the given sentence that has an error in it. If there is no error, choose 'No error'. My visiting to my family are few and far between.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'my visits' will be used instead of 'my visiting to'. Because 'my' is a determiner which is always used before noun and for plural verb 'are' 'visits' (plural noun) will be used. Correct sentence :- My visits to my family are few and far between.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error. Platinum is costlier than any other metals found on earth.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'Metal' would be appropriate in place of 'metals' because singular noun is used with any other. Correct sentence : ''Platinum is costlier than any other metal found on earth."

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error. After a heated argument they went to their respective place.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'respective places' will be used instead of 'respective place', because it is clear from the use of plural possessive adjective (their) in the sentence that noun also will be plural after it. Hence, the use of 'places' would be appropriate. Correct Sentence :- ''After a heated argument they went to their respective Places.''

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error. This coffee is not available in any of the shop in the neighborhood market.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'any of the shops, will be used in place of 'any of the shop'. Because plural form of noun/pronoun is used after 'any of the'. Hence the use of shops (plural) would be appropriate. Correct Sentence :- This coffee is not available in any of the shops in the neighborhood market.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error from the given options. Its a good idea to read up on a company before going for an interview.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence 'It's' would be appropriate instead of 'its' because 'its' is possessive adhective which will not be used instead of subject. The sort form of it's is it is and it is used in place of subject + verb. Correct Sentence :- It's a good idea to read up on a company before going for an interview.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error from the given options. The sense of sight is one of the most important senses gift to us.
Spotting error.explanation: In the above sentence, 'gifts' will be used in place of gift, because noun is always used in plural form after one of the. Correct sentence :- The sense of sight is one of the most important senses gifts to us.

Spotting error.question: Identify the segment in the sentence which contains the grammatical error from the given options. Some people lose their eye sights because of a disease or injury.
